content:
Ambient Music（氛围音乐、环境音乐）是一种将重点放在氛围上的音乐风格，不同于传统音乐对音乐结构/节奏/旋律的强调。其没有十分突出的音调，但能唤起人们较强的视听感受。这种类型的音乐会让人沉浸其中乃至于会感觉不到音乐本身。Ambient 强调情绪的表达与氛围的渲染，常常通过高品质的音色以及合音达到目的，正因如此，其缺少一般音乐所具有的节奏感，旋律，以及结构。自然界的音效会通过采样包含其中，而钢琴、弦乐和长笛等乐器的声音会通过合成器来模拟。

 

Ambient起源于1960年代和1970年代，当时诸如合成器之类的新乐器被引入了更广阔的市场。它以埃里克·萨蒂（Erik Satie）的Furniture Music（家具音乐）和如Musique Concrète，Minimal Music，牙买加Dub Music和德国电子音乐）等风格为先驱。1978年，英国音乐家布莱恩·埃诺（Brian Eno）的专辑《Ambient 1：Music for Airports》引起了人们的广泛关注，并提出和推广了Ambient的概念。Eno认为Ambient“必须满足各个听觉注意力层次，不能只强调某一个特定的层次；也必须既能让人忽略它的存在，但又非常地有趣。”。因为其相对开放的风格，ambient往往会受到以下几种音乐的影响：house, dub,industrial 和 new age 等。到1980年代后期，house和电子音乐的兴起引起了复兴，并在1990年代引起了追捧。Ambient可能具有新时代音乐和Drone的元素，因为某些作品可能会使用持续音符或重复音符。

 

Ambient在商业上并没有取得很大的成功，被批评为 "枯燥 "和 "过度知识化 "的声音。不过，这些年来，特别是在互联网时代，它还是获得了一定的好评。由于其相对开放的风格，Ambient经常受到许多其他流派的影响，包括古典音乐、前卫音乐、民谣、爵士乐和世界音乐等等。

 

历史

起源

20世纪早期的法国作曲家埃里克·萨蒂（Erik Satie）运用了达达主义（ Dadaist）启发的探索，创造了一种早期形式的Ambient/Background（氛围/背景）音乐，并将其命名为“Furniture Music（家具音乐）”（Musique d'ameublement）。他将其描述为可以在晚餐期间播放的音乐，从而能为晚餐活动创造背景氛围，而不喧宾夺主。

 

Ambient音乐重要先驱Erik Satie

By Inconnu - Erik Satie (1865-1925) en 1909 - Médiathèque musicale Mahler - Paris, Public Domain, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?curid=35632293

 

用自己的话说，他试图创造“一种音乐……它将成为环境噪音的一部分，并将它们纳入日常听觉考量的范围。我认为它应该是是悠扬的，可以减轻晚餐时刀叉的噪音，不占主导地位，这将填补有时在朋友聚在一起用餐时的沉寂，使他们免于陷入无话可讲的境地，同时也消除了街头的喧嚣，让人可以更为舒适地参与对话的过程。制作这样的音乐将是对这种需求的回应。”

 

1948年，法国作曲家和工程师Pierre Schaeffer创造了术语Musique Concrète（具象音乐）。这种音乐的实验风格使用自然声音的录音，然后对其进行修改，操纵或影响以创作乐曲。Shaeffer使用磁带循环和剪切拼接的技术被认为是现代采样的先驱。

 

1952年，约翰·凯奇发布了他著名的三乐章作品《4'33》（4分33秒），这是一场持续4分33秒的完全沉默无声的音乐表演。该乐曲旨在捕捉表演场地/地点的环境声音，并以此作为播放的音乐。凯恩（Cage）被像Brian Eno这样的开创性艺术家称为其灵感影响的来源。

 

1960s

60年代，许多音乐团体尝试了特别的方法制作音乐，其中一些方式创造了后来被称为Ambient的音乐形式。

 

1962年夏天，作曲家拉蒙·桑德（Ramon Sender）和莫顿·苏伯尼克（Morton Subotnick）创立了旧金山录音音乐中心，既充当电子音乐工作室，又充当音乐会场地。其它一些研究磁带录音机的作曲家也成为了成员和合作者，其中包括Pauline Oliveros，Terry Riley和Steve Reich。他们的作品除促进了Minimal Music极简音乐的发展（也称为极简主义），这种音乐与Ambient有着许多相似的概念，例如重复的模式或脉冲，稳定的Drone和辅音和声。

 

1960 年代中期至 1990 年代中期，在欧洲和美国发行了许多唱片，这些唱片确立了英语流行音乐市场中Ambient流派的基调。一些带有Ambient元素的 1960 年代唱片包括 Tony Scott 的 Music for Yoga Meditation and Other Joys 和 Music for Zen Meditation、Raymond Scott 的 Soothing Sounds for Baby，以及 Irv Teibel 的第一张Environments专辑系列。

 

60年代后期，法国作曲家Éliane Radigue通过处理来自两个磁带录音机和麦克风之间的反馈的磁带循环，创作了几首作品。在70年代，她接着几乎完全用ARP 2500合成器来创作相似的音乐，而且她漫长而缓慢的音乐作品经常被与Drone音乐进行比较。1969年，COUM Transmissions小组在英国艺术学校进行了声波实验。

 

1970s

在1970年代发展起来的Ambient源于该时期以实验和合成器为导向的风格。

 

1974年至1976年之间，美国作曲家劳里·斯皮格尔（Laurie Spiegel）在计算机模拟混合系统GROOVE上创作了开创性作品《The Expanding Universe》。 1977年，她的作品《Music of the Spheres》被旅行者飞行器携带的的Voyager 1 & 2 Golden Records收录。

 

1975年4月，Suzanne Ciani在其Buchla合成器上进行了两次表演-一场在WBAI Free音乐商店，另一场在Phil Niblock的家中。这些表演在2016年的专辑《Buchla Concerts 1975》中发行。根据厂牌信息，这些音乐会既是现场演讲，又是赠款申请，也是教育演示。

 

但是，直到Brian Eno在70年代中期创造了这个术语，Ambient才被定义为一种流派。埃诺（Eno）考虑到这一点，继续录制了1975年的专辑Discreet Music，建议以“相对较低的音量水平收听，即使其程度经常低于可听性的阈值”，指的是萨蒂（Satie）关于他的家具音乐/环境音乐的概念。

 

其他当时创作Ambient风格音乐的同期音乐家包括牙买加Dub音乐家，例如King Tubby，日本电子音乐作曲家，例如Isita Tomita 和Ryuichi Sakamoto，以及Irv Teibel的关注心理声场的Environments系列，以及诸如Popol Vuh，Ash Ra Tempel和Tangerine Dream之类的德国乐队。

 

现代音乐中合成器的兴起对Ambient风格的影响是不可估量的。正如早期电子先驱Kraftwerk的Ralf Hutter在1977年Billboard采访中所说的那样：“电子超越了国家和色彩……有了电子，一切皆有可能。唯一的限制就是作曲家。” Yellow Magic Orchestra（黄色魔术乐团）开发环境的不同风格的电子音乐，后来发展成为Ambient House音乐。

 

Brian Eno

英国制作人Brian Eno在1970年代中期创造了“Ambient”一词。他说其他艺术家一直在创作类似的音乐，但是“我只是给它起了一个名字。这正是它所需要的。通过命名某些东西，您就可以创造出与众不同。您说，这已经是真实的了。名字非常重要。 ” 他用这个词来描述与canned music形式（例如Muzak）不同的音乐。

 

Ambient术语的发明者Brian Eno

By cosciansky - originally posted to Flickr as Life of Brian, CC BY 2.0, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?curid=11935710

 

在他1978年的专辑Ambient 1: Music for Airports的内页中，Eno写道：

 

“现有的唱片音乐公司通过覆盖其声学和大气的特异性，从规范环境的基础上着手，而Ambient旨在加强这些特性。传统的背景音乐是通过从音乐中剥离所有的怀疑和不确定感而产生的，而Ambient则保留了这些品质。而他们的目的是通过增加刺激来 "照亮 "环境（据说可以减轻日常工作的乏味，平缓身体节奏的自然起伏），Ambient的目的是提供平静和思考的空间。Ambient必须能够适应多种层次的听觉感知，而不强求某一种；因为它的有趣性，所以它可以被忽略。”

 

Eno将自己描述为“非音乐家”，称自己的音乐实验为“治疗”，而不是传统音乐表演。

 

1980s

在70年代后期，New-age音乐家Laraaji开始在纽约的公园和人行道（包括华盛顿广场公园）里街头卖艺。布莱恩·埃诺（Brian Eno）在那儿听到拉拉吉（Laraaji）的演奏，问他是否想录制专辑。1980年，Laraaji的专辑Day of Radiance发行，由Eno操刀制作，这是Eno的Ambient系列中的第三张专辑。尽管Laraaji已经录制了许多专辑，但这张专辑使他获得了国际认可。与该系列中的其他专辑不同，《Day of Radiance》主要采用声学乐器而非电子乐器。

 

在1980年代中期，通过使用采样创建可视化声波图像的可能性增加了。到1980年代后期，计算机在音乐的写入和录制过程中的结合已急剧增加。具有内置声音设备和IBM模型的16位Macintosh平台将在音乐家和唱片制作人的录音室和家庭中找到自己的位置。

 

但是，许多艺术家仍在使用模拟合成器和声学仪器来制作Ambient作品。

 

1983年，高田美纪里（Midori Takada）在两天内录制了她的首张个人专辑《Through The Looking Glass》。她演奏了专辑中的所有部分，并使用了各种乐器，包括打击乐器，马林巴琴，锣，芦苇风琴，铃铛，阿卡丽娜，颤音琴，钢琴和可口可乐玻璃瓶。

 

在1988年至1993年之间，Éliane Radigue用ARP 2500制作了三个小时的作品，随后以La Trilogie De La Mort的形式一起发行。

 

此外，在1988年，旧金山磁带音乐中心的创始成员和总监Pauline Oliveros在华盛顿的一个能营造45秒的混响时间的巨大的地下蓄水池中录制专辑后，提出了“深度聆听”的概念。深度聆听的概念继而成为“基于即兴创作，电子音乐，仪式，教学和冥想原理的美学”。

 

1990s

到1990年代初期，Orb，Aphex Twin，Seefeel，the Irresistible Force, Biosphere, 和the Higher Intelligence Agency等艺术家获得了商业上的成功，并被流行音乐媒体称为Ambient House，Ambient Techno，IDM或简称“Ambient”。而“Chillout”一词起源于英国的ecstasy文化，最初被用在主舞池外的放松的降速“Chillout Rooms（休憩室）”中，在这里，Ambient，Dub和Downtempo得到表演，以缓解晕眩癫狂的情绪。

 

伦敦的艺术家，例如Aphex Twin（特别是：《Selected Ambient Works Volume II》(1994年），《Global Communication》（76：14，1994年），《The Future Sound of London》（Lifeforms，1994年，ISDN，1994年），《The Black Dog》（Temple of Transparent Balls，1993年），Autechre（Incunabula，1993年，Amber，1994年），Boards of Canada和KLF 's Chill Out，（1990年），都参与了Ambient的普及和多样化，并以此作为冷静喘息的机会，让乐迷从当时流行的Hardcore和Techno的强度中舒缓下来。

 

1990年代的其他全球Ambient艺术家包括美国作曲家Stars of the Lid（在该十年中发行了5张专辑）和日本艺术家Susumu Yokota，其专辑Sakura（1999年）将Pitchfork杂志称为“梦幻的，经过处理的吉他作为独特的声音工具” ”。

 

2000s至今

在2000年代，Ambient继续受到欢迎，许多成熟和新兴艺术家出版了作品，获得了广泛好评。

 

2011年，美国作曲家利兹·哈里斯（Liz Harris）以Grouper的身份发行了专辑AIA：Alien Observer，该专辑在Pitchfork的“有史以来50最佳Ambient专辑”中排名第21。

 

2011年，朱莉安娜·巴威克（Julianna Barwick）发行了她的第一张全长专辑《The Magic Place》。Barwick受童年时在教堂合唱团的经历的影响很大，将她无语的人声循环成空灵的音景。它在Pitchfork的50份有史以来最佳Ambient专辑中排名第30位。

 

2014年10月，一位前Riot-grrrl成员乔·约翰逊（Jo Johnson）发行了出人意料的首张专辑《Weaving》。 Pitchfork杂志以重复的音序，琶音和Drone为特色，将该专辑描述为“对Ambient的杰出成就”。

 

经过几张自我发行的专辑，Buchla合成器作曲家，制作人和表演者Kaitlyn Aurelia Smith于2015年与独立唱片公司Western Vinyl签约。 2016年，她发行了第二张官方专辑EARS。它将Buchla合成器与传统乐器配对，她的作品与Laurie Spiegel和Alice Coltrane进行了比较。Kaitlyn还与其他著名的布赫拉（Buchla）表演者苏珊·齐亚尼（Suzanne Ciani）合作。

 

到2000年代末和2010年代末，Ambient在YouTube上也获得了广泛认可，其上传的作品通常长达1到8个小时不等，获得了数以百万计的点击量。这样的视频通常以“Relaxing Music（放松音乐）”为标题，并且可能会受到其他音乐流派的影响。Ambient音乐视频可以帮助在线听众进行瑜伽，学习，睡觉（，按摩，冥想并获得乐观，启发，并在他们的房间或其他环境中营造宁静的氛围。

 

许多上载的Ambient视频往往会受到Biomusic（生物音乐）的影响，在这些视频中，它们会表现出自然的声音，不过声音会通过混响和延迟单元进行修改，以使声音的空间版本成为环境的一部分。这种自然的声音常常包括那些，沙滩，热带雨林，雷暴和降雨，除其他外，与动物的发声如鸟鸣被使用。包含双耳节拍的乐曲也很常见，也很流行，可提供音乐疗法和倾听者的压力管理。

 

经过验证的YouTube频道（例如Ambient）拥有超过40万订阅者。还可以发布Ambient的其他经过验证的渠道包括：冥想放松音乐（Meditation Relax Music），拥有超过100万的订阅者；Soothing Relaxation，拥有300万的订阅者；以及Relaxing White Noise，拥有超过50万的订阅者。iTunes和Spotify上也有以Ambient为特色的数字广播，主要是由独立厂牌制作发布。

 

这个时代比较知名的Ambient音乐（根据Pitchfork杂志）包括来自Max Richter，Julianna Barwick，Grouper，William Basinski和电子艺术家Oneohtrix Point Never的作品。

 

相关和衍生流派

Ambient Dub

Ambient Dub是Ambient与Dub（一种雷鬼音乐与电子音乐的融合风格）的融合。这个词最早是由伯明翰（Birmingham）现已停业的唱片公司“超越唱片”（Beyond Records）于1990年代初创造的。该唱片公司发行了一系列专辑Ambient Dub Volume 1-4，启发了许多艺术家，包括Bill Laswell，后者在他的音乐项目Divination中使用了相同的描述，在那里他与该类型的其他艺术家合作。Ambient Dub采用Tubby King出名的Dub风格和其他1960年代至1970年代初的牙买加声音艺术家，都使用DJ启发的Ambient电子音乐，并具有所有固有的衰减，回声，均衡和迷幻的电子效果。它通常具有分层技术，并融合了世界音乐，深沉的低音线条和和声的元素。根据David Toop的说法，“Ambient Dub就像漫长的回声延迟，随着时间的流逝而循环……将音乐序列的合理顺序变成了一片轰动的海洋。” 在Ambient Dub风格之内著名的艺术家包括Dreadzone, Higher Intelligence Agency, The Orb, Gaudi, Ott, Loop Guru, Woob and Transglobal Underground以及Banco de Gaia等。

 

Ambient House

Ambient House是成立于1980年代后期的音乐类别，用于描述具有Ambient元素和氛围的Acid House。Ambient House类型中的曲目通常具有Four on the floor节拍，合成器Pads和以及大气质感的人声样本。Ambient House音乐通常没有diatonic center（全音调中心），并且具有很多调式特征以及合成和弦。荷兰的Brainvoyager就是这种类型的一个例子。Illbient是Ambient House的另一种形式。

 

Ambient Techno

Ambient Techno是一个20世纪80年代末出现的音乐类别，使用来自Techno的节奏和旋律元素描述Ambient氛围。著名的艺术家包括Aphex Twin，B12，Autechre和The Black Dog。

 

Ambient Industrial

Ambient Industrial是Industrial和Ambient音乐的混合体。术语“Industrial”是在原始实验意义上使用的，而不是在Industrial Metal的意义上使用的。“典型的”Ambient Industrial作品可能包括金属轰鸣和共振，极端低频隆隆声和机器噪声的不断演变的不和谐，也许由锣，敲击节奏，Bullroarers（牛吼器），失真声音引起，或其他艺术家可能会喜欢采样的东西（通常会处理到无法再识别原始采样的程度）。对于Ambient Industrial，整首作品可能甚至会基于射电望远镜录音，新生婴儿的胡言乱语或通过电报线中的接触式麦克风录制的声音。

 

Ambient Pop

Ambient Pop音乐是Dream Pop的延伸，具有传统流行音乐常见的形状和形式，而其电子纹理和氛围则反映了Ambient沉思的特质。它受krautrock的律动旋律影响，但磨蚀性较小。

 

Dark Ambient

布赖恩·埃诺（Brian Eno）最初对Ambient的看法是不引人注目的背景音乐，后来与温暖的House节奏融为一体，并在1990年代被The Orb赋予了有趣味性的内容，但这些在Dark Ambient中表现出了完全相反的品质。这种风格由一众人所倡导，从较老的工业和金属实验艺术家（Scorn的Mick Harris，现任93的David Tibet，Nurse with Wound的Steven Stapleton）到electronic boffins（Kim Cascone / PGR，Psychick Warriors Ov Gaia）），日本的噪音艺术家（KK Null，Merzbow）和后来的独立摇滚歌手（Main，“ Bark Psychosis”）–Dark Ambient的特征有在节拍上音调比例的减小甚至完全消失，并带有令人不安的键盘，令人毛骨悚然的采样和经过处理的吉他效果。就像大多数与90年代的电子/舞蹈音乐有某种联系的风格一样，这是一个非常模糊的名词。许多艺术家在发布作品时都会游走在这个风格的边界。与之相关的风格包括Ambient Industrial和Isolationist Ambient。

 

Space Music

Space music太空音乐，也被拼写为“ Spacemusic”，包括来自周围流派的音乐以及具有某些共同特征的多种其他流派，以营造沉思的宽敞感。

 

太空音乐的范围从简单到复杂，有时缺乏常规的旋律，节奏或声音成分，通常让人联想到“空间图像和情感的连续性”，有益的内省，深度聆听以及漂浮，巡航或飞行的感觉。

 

个体通常使用耳机将空间音乐用于背景增强和前景聆听，以刺激放松，沉思，灵感和通常和平的扩张性情绪和音景。太空音乐也是许多电影配乐的组成部分，通常被用作天文馆的放松辅助和冥想。

 

知名Ambient音乐节目

  • Sirius XM Chill 播放Ambient、Chillout和Downtempo电子乐。
  • Echoes 成立于 1989 年，在美国 130 家广播电台联合播放，是一个每天两小时的音乐广播节目，由 John Diliberto 主持，以Ambient、Spacemusic、电子音乐、New acoustic和新音乐方向的音景为特色。
  • Hearts of Space，由斯蒂芬希尔主持的节目，自 1973 年起在美国 NPR 上播出。
  • Musical Starstreams 是一家总部位于美国的商业广播电台和互联网节目，自 1981 年以来由 Forest 制作、编程和主持。
  • Star's End，宾夕法尼亚州费城 88.5 WXPN 的广播节目。 它成立于 1976 年，是世界上运行时间第二长的Ambient音乐广播节目。
  • Ultima Thule Ambient Music，自 1989 年以来在澳大利亚各地的社区电台每周播放 90 分钟的节目。
  • Avaruusromua 这个名字的意思是“空间碎片”，是自 1990 年以来在芬兰公共广播公司 YLE 的各个电台播放的 60 分钟Ambient和Avant-garde广播节目。
contentEn:
Ambient music is a genre of music that emphasizes tone and atmosphere over traditional musical structure or rhythm. A form of instrumental music, it may lack net composition, beat, or structured melody.[5] It uses textural layers of sound which can reward both passive and active listening[6] and encourage a sense of calm or contemplation.[7][8] The genre is said to evoke an "atmospheric", "visual",[9] or "unobtrusive" quality.[10] Nature soundscapes may be included, and the sounds of acoustic instruments such as the piano, strings and flute may be emulated through a synthesizer.[11]

 

The genre originated in the 1960s and 1970s, when new musical instruments were being introduced to a wider market, such as the synthesizer.[12] It was presaged by Erik Satie's furniture music and styles such as musique concrète, minimal music, Jamaican dub music and German electronic music, but was prominently named and popularized by British musician Brian Eno in 1978 with his album Ambient 1: Music for Airports; Eno opined that ambient music "must be as ignorable as it is interesting."[13] It saw a revival towards the late 1980s with the prominence of house and techno music, growing a cult following by the 1990s.[14] Ambient music may have elements of new-age music and drone music, as some works may use sustained or repeated notes.[15]

 

Ambient music did not achieve large commercial success, being criticized as having a "boring" and "over-intellectual" sound.[16] Nevertheless, it has attained a certain degree of acclaim throughout the years, especially in the Internet age. Due to its relatively open style, ambient music often takes influences from many other genres, ranging from classical, avant-garde music, folk, jazz, and world music, amongst others.[17][18]

 

History

Origins

As an early 20th-century French composer, Erik Satie used such Dadaist-inspired explorations to create an early form of ambient/background music that he labeled "furniture music" (Musique d'ameublement). This he described as being the sort of music that could be played during a dinner to create a background atmosphere for that activity, rather than serving as the focus of attention.[19]

 

In his own words, Satie sought to create "a music...which will be part of the noises of the environment, will take them into consideration. I think of it as melodious, softening the noises of the knives and forks at dinner, not dominating them, not imposing itself. It would fill up those heavy silences that sometime fall between friends dining together. It would spare them the trouble of paying attention to their own banal remarks. And at the same time it would neutralize the street noises which so indiscreetly enter into the play of conversation. To make such music would be to respond to a need."[20][21]

 

In 1948, French composer & engineer, Pierre Schaeffer coined the term musique concrète. This experimental style of music used recordings of natural sounds that were then modified, manipulated or effected to create a composition.[22] Shaeffer's techniques of using tape loops and splicing are considered to be the precursor to modern day sampling.

 

In 1952 John Cage released his famous three-movement composition[23][24] 4'33 which is a performance of complete silence for four minutes and thirty-three seconds. The piece is intended to capture the ambient sounds of the venue/location of the performance and have that be the music played.[25] Cage has been cited by seminal artists such as Brian Eno as influence.[25]

 

1960s

In the 1960s, many music groups experimented with unusual methods, with some of them creating what would later be called ambient music.

 

In the summer of 1962, composers Ramon Sender and Morton Subotnick founded The San Francisco Tape Music Center which functioned both as an electronic music studio and concert venue.[26] Other composers working with tape recorders became members and collaborators including Pauline Oliveros, Terry Riley and Steve Reich. Their compositions, among others, contributed to the development of minimal music (also called minimalism), which shares many similar concepts to ambient music such as repetitive patterns or pulses, steady drones, and consonant harmony.[27]

 

Many records were released in Europe and the United States of America between the mid-1960s and the mid-1990s that established the conventions of the ambient genre in the anglophone popular music market.[28] Some 1960s records with ambient elements include Music for Yoga Meditation and Other Joys and Music for Zen Meditation by Tony Scott, Soothing Sounds for Baby by Raymond Scott, and the first record of the Environments (album series) by Irv Teibel.

 

In the late 60s, French composer Éliane Radigue composed several pieces by processing tape loops from the feedback between two tape recorders and a microphone.[29] In the 70s, she then went on to compose similar music almost exclusively with an ARP 2500 synthesiser, and her long, slow compositions have often been compared to drone music.[30][31] In 1969, the group COUM Transmissions were performing sonic experiments in British art schools.[32]

 

1970s

Developing in the 1970s, ambient music stemmed from the experimental and synthesizer-oriented styles of the period.

 

Between 1974 and 1976, American composer Laurie Spiegel created her seminal work The Expanding Universe, created on a computer-analog hybrid system called GROOVE.[33] In 1977, her composition, Music of the Spheres was included on Voyager 1 and 2's Golden Record.[34]

 

In April 1975, Suzanne Ciani gave two performances on her Buchla synthesizer - one at the WBAI Free music store and one at Phil Niblock's loft.[35] These performances were released on an archival album in 2016 entitled Buchla Concerts 1975. According to the record label, these concerts were part live presentation, part grant application and part educational demonstration.[36]

 

However, it wasn't until Brian Eno coined the term in the mid-70s that ambient music was defined as a genre. Eno went on to record 1975's Discreet Music with this in mind, suggesting that it be listened to at "comparatively low levels, even to the extent that it frequently falls below the threshold of audibility",[20] referring to Satie's quote about his musique d'ameublement.[37]

 

Other contemporaneous musicians creating ambient-style music at the time included Jamaican dub musicians such as King Tubby,[2] Japanese electronic music composers such as Isao Tomita[3][4] and Ryuichi Sakamoto as well as the psychoacoustic soundscapes of Irv Teibel's Environments series, and German bands such as Popol Vuh, Ash Ra Tempel and Tangerine Dream.

 

The impact the rise of the synthesizer in modern music had on ambient as a genre cannot be overstated; as Ralf Hutter of early electronic pioneers Kraftwerk said in a 1977 Billboard interview: "Electronics is beyond nations and colors...with electronics everything is possible. The only limit is with the composer".[38] The Yellow Magic Orchestra developed a distinct style of ambient electronic music that would later be developed into ambient house music.[39]

 

Brian Eno

The English producer Brian Eno is credited with coining the term "ambient music" in the mid-1970s. He said other artists had been creating similar music, but that "I just gave it a name. Which is exactly what it needed ... By naming something you create a difference. You say that this is now real. Names are very important."[40] He used the term to describe music that is different from forms of canned music like Muzak.[41]

 

In the liner notes for his 1978 album Ambient 1: Music for Airports, Eno wrote:[42]

Whereas the extant canned music companies proceed from the basis of regularizing environments by blanketing their acoustic and atmospheric idiosyncrasies, Ambient Music is intended to enhance these. Whereas conventional background music is produced by stripping away all sense of doubt and uncertainty (and thus all genuine interest) from the music, Ambient Music retains these qualities. And whereas their intention is to "brighten" the environment by adding stimulus to it (thus supposedly alleviating the tedium of routine tasks and leveling out the natural ups and downs of the body rhythms) Ambient Music is intended to induce calm and a space to think. Ambient Music must be able to accommodate many levels of listening attention without enforcing one in particular; it must be as ignorable as it is interesting.

 

Eno, who describes himself as a "non-musician", termed his experiments "treatments" rather than traditional performances.[42][43]

 

1980s

In the late 70s, new-age musician Laraaji began busking in New York parks and sidewalks, including Washington Square Park. It was there that Brian Eno heard Laraaji playing and asked him if he'd like to record an album. Day of Radiance released in 1980, was the third album in Eno's Ambient series. Although Laraaji had already recorded a number of albums, this one gave him international recognition.[44] Unlike other albums in the series, Day of Radiance featured mostly acoustic instruments instead of electronics.

 

In the mid-1980s, the possibilities to create a sonic landscape increased through the use of sampling. By the late 1980s, there was a steep increase in the incorporation of the computer in the writing and recording process of records. The sixteen-bit Macintosh platform with built-in sound and comparable IBM models would find themselves in studios and homes of musicians and record makers.[45]

 

However, many artists were still working with analogue synthesizers and acoustic instruments to produce ambient works.

 

In 1983, Midori Takada recorded her first solo LP Through The Looking Glass in two days. She performed all parts on the album, with diverse instrumentation including percussion, marimba, gong, reed organ, bells, ocarina, vibraphone, piano and glass Coca-Cola bottles.[46]

 

Between 1988 and 1993 Éliane Radigue produced three hour-long works on the ARP 2500 which were subsequently issued together as La Trilogie De La Mort.[47]

 

Also in 1988, founding member and director of the San Francisco Tape Music Centre, Pauline Oliveros coined the term "deep listening" after she recorded an album inside a huge underground cistern in Washington which has a 45-second reverberation time. The concept of Deep Listening then went on to become "an aesthetic based upon principles of improvisation, electronic music, ritual, teaching and meditation".[48]

 

1990s

By the early 1990s, artists such as the Orb, Aphex Twin, Seefeel, the Irresistible Force, Biosphere, and the Higher Intelligence Agency gained commercial success and were being referred to by the popular music press as ambient house, ambient techno, IDM or simply "ambient". The term chillout emerged from British ecstasy culture which was originally applied in relaxed downtempo "chillout rooms" outside of the main dance floor where ambient, dub and downtempo beats were played to ease the tripping mind.[49][50]

 

London artists such as Aphex Twin (specifically: Selected Ambient Works Volume II, 1994), Global Communication (76:14, 1994), The Future Sound of London (Lifeforms, 1994, ISDN, 1994), The Black Dog (Temple of Transparent Balls, 1993), Autechre (Incunabula, 1993, Amber, 1994), Boards of Canada, and The KLF's Chill Out, (1990), all took a part in popularising and diversifying ambient music where it was used as a calming respite from the intensity of the hardcore and techno popular at that time.[49]

 

Other global ambient artists from the 1990s include American composers Stars of the Lid (who released 5 albums during this decade), and Japanese artist Susumu Yokota whose album Sakura (1999) featured what Pitchfork magazine called "dreamy, processed guitar as a distinctive sound tool".[51]

 

2000s–present

Ambient music continued to gain popularity in the 2000s with a number of established and emerging artists published works to critical acclaim.

 

In 2011, American composer Liz Harris recording as Grouper released the album AIA: Alien Observer, listed by Pitchfork at number 21 on their "50 Best Ambient Albums of All Time".[52]

 

In 2011, Julianna Barwick released her first full-length album The Magic Place. Heavily influenced by her childhood experiences in a church choir, Barwick loops her wordless vocals into ethereal soundscapes.[53] It was listed at number 30 on Pitchfork's 50 Best Ambient Albums of All Time.[54]

 

In October 2014, an ex riot-grrrl band member Jo Johnson released an unexpected debut album Weaving.[55] Featuring repetitive sequences, arpeggios and drones, Pitchfork magazine described the album as "a remarkably accomplished take on ambient music".[56]

 

After several self-released albums, Buchla composer, producer and performer Kaitlyn Aurelia Smith was signed to independent record label Western Vinyl in 2015.[57] In 2016, she released her second official album EARS. It paired the Buchla synthesizer with traditional instruments and her compositions were compared to Laurie Spiegel and Alice Coltrane.[58] Kaitlyn has also collaborated with other well-known Buchla performer, Suzanne Ciani.[59]

 

By the late 2000s and 2010s, ambient music also gained widespread recognition on YouTube, with uploaded pieces, usually ranging from 1 to 8 hours long, getting over millions of hits. Such videos are usually titled, or are generally known as, "relaxing music", and may be influenced by other music genres. Ambient videos assist online listeners with yoga, study, sleep (see music and sleep), massage, meditation and gaining optimism, inspiration, and creating peaceful atmosphere in their rooms or other environments.[60]

 

Many uploaded ambient videos tend to be influenced by biomusic where they feature sounds of nature, though the sounds would be modified with reverbs and delay units to make spacey versions of the sounds as part of the ambience. Such natural sounds oftentimes include those of a beach, rainforest, thunderstorm and rainfall, among others, with vocalizations of animals such as bird songs being used as well. Pieces containing binaural beats are common and popular uploads as well, which provide music therapy and stress management for the listener.[61]

 

Verified YouTube channels, such as aptly titled Ambient has over 400,000 subscribers.[62] Other verified channels that also publish ambient music include, Meditation Relax Music, which has over 1 million subscribers,[63] Soothing Relaxation with three million subscribers,[64] and Relaxing White Noise with over 500,000 subscribers, among others. iTunes and Spotify have digital radio stations that feature ambient music, which are mostly produced by independent labels.[5]

 

Acclaimed ambient music of this era (according to Pitchfork magazine) include works by Max Richter, Julianna Barwick, Grouper, William Basinski, Oneohtrix Point Never, and the Caretaker.[65][66][67][68]

 

Related and derivative genres

Ambient dub

Ambient dub is a fusion of ambient music with dub. The term was first coined by Birmingham's now defunct label "Beyond Records" in early 1990s. The label released series of albums Ambient Dub Volume 1 to 4 that inspired many artists, including Bill Laswell, who used the same phrase in his music project Divination, where he collaborated with other artists in the genre. Ambient dub adopts dub styles made famous by King Tubby and other Jamaican sound artists from the 1960s to the early 1970s, using DJ-inspired ambient electronica, complete with all the inherent drop-outs, echo, equalization and psychedelic electronic effects. It often features layering techniques and incorporates elements of world music, deep bass lines and harmonic sounds.[2] According to David Toop, "Dub music is like a long echo delay, looping through time...turning the rational order of musical sequences into an ocean of sensation."[69] Notable artists within the genre include Dreadzone, Higher Intelligence Agency, The Orb, Gaudi,[70] Ott, Loop Guru, Woob and Transglobal Underground[71] as well as Banco de Gaia.

 

Ambient house

Ambient house is a musical category founded in the late 1980s that is used to describe acid house featuring ambient music elements and atmospheres.[72] Tracks in the ambient house genre typically feature four-on-the-floor beats, synth pads, and vocal samples integrated in an atmospheric style.[72] Ambient house tracks generally lack a diatonic center and feature much atonality along with synthesized chords. The Dutch Brainvoyager is an example of this genre. Illbient is another form of ambient house music.

 

Ambient techno

Ambient techno is a music category emerging in the late 1980s that is used to describe ambient music atmospheres with the rhythmic and melodic elements of techno.[73] Notable artists include Aphex Twin, B12, Autechre, and The Black Dog.

 

Ambient industrial

Ambient industrial is a hybrid genre of industrial and ambient music; the term industrial being used in the original experimental sense, rather than in the sense of industrial metal.[74] A "typical" ambient industrial work (if there is such a thing) might consist of evolving dissonant harmonies of metallic drones and resonances, extreme low frequency rumbles and machine noises, perhaps supplemented by gongs, percussive rhythms, bullroarers, distorted voices or anything else the artist might care to sample (often processed to the point where the original sample is no longer recognizable).[74] Entire works may be based on radio telescope recordings, the babbling of newborn babies, or sounds recorded through contact microphones on telegraph wires.[74]

 

Ambient pop

Ambient pop is an extension of dream pop, possessing a shape and form common to conventional pop, while its electronic textures and atmospheres mirror the meditative qualities of ambient. It is influenced by the lock-groove melodies of krautrock, but is less abrasive.[75]

 

Dark ambient

Brian Eno's original vision of ambient music as unobtrusive musical wallpaper, later fused with warm house rhythms and given playful qualities by the Orb in the 1990s, found its opposite in the style known as dark ambient. Populated by a wide assortment of personalities—ranging from older industrial and metal experimentalists (Scorn's Mick Harris, Current 93's David Tibet, Nurse with Wound's Steven Stapleton) to electronic boffins (Kim Cascone/PGR, Psychick Warriors Ov Gaia), Japanese noise artists (K.K. Null, Merzbow), and latter-day indie rockers (Main, Bark Psychosis) – dark ambient features toned-down or entirely missing beats with unsettling passages of keyboards, eerie samples, and treated guitar effects. Like most styles related in some way to electronic/dance music of the '90s, it's a very nebulous term; many artists enter or leave the style with each successive release.[76] Related styles include ambient industrial (see below) and isolationist ambient.

 

Space music

Space music, also spelled "Spacemusic", includes music from the ambient genre as well as a broad range of other genres with certain characteristics in common to create the experience of contemplative spaciousness.[77][78][79]

 

Space music ranges from simple to complex sonic textures sometimes lacking conventional melodic, rhythmic, or vocal components,[80][81] generally evoking a sense of "continuum of spatial imagery and emotion",[82] beneficial introspection, deep listening[83] and sensations of floating, cruising or flying.[84][85]

 

Space music is used by individuals for both background enhancement and foreground listening, often with headphones, to stimulate relaxation, contemplation, inspiration and generally peaceful expansive moods[86] and soundscapes. Space music is also a component of many film soundtracks and is commonly used in planetariums, as a relaxation aid and for meditation.[87]

 

Notable ambient-music shows on radio and via satellite – Over The Air

  • Sirius XM Chill plays ambient, chillout and downtempo electronica.
  • Echoes, a daily two-hour music radio program hosted by John Diliberto featuring a soundscape of ambient, spacemusic, electronica, new acoustic and new music directions – founded in 1989 and syndicated on 130 radio stations in the USA.
  • Hearts of Space, a program hosted by Stephen Hill and broadcast on NPR in the US since 1973.[88][89]
  • Musical Starstreams, a US-based commercial radio station and Internet program produced, programmed and hosted by Forest since 1981.
  • Star's End, a radio show on 88.5 WXPN, in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. Founded in 1976, it is the second longest-running ambient music radio show in the world.[90]
  • Ultima Thule Ambient Music, a weekly 90-minute show broadcast since 1989 on community radio across Australia.
  • Avaruusromua, the name meaning "space debris", is a 60-minute ambient and avant-garde radio program broadcast since 1990 on Finnish public broadcaster YLE's various stations.[91]

  77. ^ "... Originally a 1970s reference to the conjunction of ambient electronics and our expanding visions of cosmic space ... In fact, almost any music with a slow pace and space-creating sound images could be called spacemusic." Stephen Hill, co-founder, Hearts of Space, What is spacemusic? Archived 2006-03-25 at the Wayback Machine
  78. ^ "Any music with a generally slow, relaxing pace and space-creating imagery or atmospherics may be considered Space Music, without conventional rhythmic elements, while drawing from any number of traditional, ethnic, or modern styles." Lloyde Barde, July/August 2004, Making Sense of the Last 20 Years in New Music Archived 2007-09-27 at the Wayback Machine
  79. ^ "When you listen to space and ambient music you are connecting with a tradition of contemplative sound experience whose roots are ancient and diverse. The genre spans historical, ethnic, and contemporary styles. In fact, almost any music with a slow pace and space-creating sound images could be called spacemusic." Stephen Hill, co-founder, Hearts of Space, What is spacemusic? Archived2006-03-25 at the Wayback Machine
  80. ^ "A timeless experience...as ancient as the echoes of a simple bamboo flute or as contemporary as the latest ambient electronica. Any music with a generally slow pace and space-creating sound image can be called spacemusic. Generally quiet, consonant, ethereal, often without conventional rhythmic and dynamic contrasts, spacemusic is found within many historical, ethnic, and contemporary genres."Stephen Hill, co-founder, Hearts of Space, sidebar "What is Spacemusic?" in essay Contemplative Music, Broadly Defined Archived 2010-12-25 at the Wayback Machine
  81. ^ "The early innovators in electronic "space music" were mostly located around Berlin. The term has come to refer to music in the style of the early and mid-1970s works of Klaus Schulze, Tangerine Dream, Ash Ra Tempel, Popol Vuh and others in that scene. The music is characterized by long compositions, looping sequencer patterns, and improvised lead melody lines." – John Dilaberto, Berlin School, Echoes Radio on-line music glossary Archived 2007-06-14 at the Wayback Machine
  82. ^ "This music is experienced primarily as a continuum of spatial imagery and emotion, rather than as thematic musical relationships, compositional ideas, or performance values." Essay by Stephen Hill, co-founder, Hearts of Space, New Age Music Made SimpleArchived 2010-04-05 at the Wayback Machine
  83. ^ "Innerspace, Meditative, and Transcendental... This music promotes a psychological movement inward." Stephen Hill, co-founder, Hearts of Space, essay titled New Age Music Made Simple Archived 2010-04-05 at the Wayback Machine
  84. ^ "...Spacemusic ... conjures up either outer "space" or "inner space" " – Lloyd Barde, founder of Backroads Music Notes on Ambient Music, Hyperreal Music Archive Archived 2007-09-29 at the Wayback Machine
  85. ^ "Space And Travel Music: Celestial, Cosmic, and Terrestrial... This New Age sub-category has the effect of outward psychological expansion. Celestial or cosmic music removes listeners from their ordinary acoustical surroundings by creating stereo sound images of vast, virtually dimensionless spatial environments. In a word — spacey. Rhythmic or tonal movements animate the experience of flying, floating, cruising, gliding, or hovering within the auditory space."Stephen Hill, co-founder, Hearts of Space, in an essay titled New Age Music Made Simple Archived 2010-04-05 at the Wayback Machine
  86. ^ " Restorative powers are often claimed for it, and at its best it can create an effective environment to balance some of the stress, noise, and complexity of everyday life." – Stephen Hill, Founder, Music from the Hearts of Space What is Spacemusic? Archived2006-03-25 at the Wayback Machine
  87. ^ "This was the soundtrack for countless planetarium shows, on massage tables, and as soundtracks to many videos and movies."- Lloyd Barde Notes on Ambient Music, Hyperreal Music ArchiveArchived 2007-09-29 at the Wayback Machine
  88. ^ "The program has defined its own niche — a mix of ambient, electronic, world, new-age, classical and experimental music....Slow-paced, space-creating music from many cultures — ancient bell meditations, classical adagios, creative space jazz, and the latest electronic and acoustic ambient music are woven into a seamless sequence unified by sound, emotion, and spatial imagery." Stephen Hill, co-founder, Hearts of Space, essay titled Contemplative Music, Broadly Defined Archived 2010-12-25 at the Wayback Machine
  89. ^ "Hill's Hearts of Space Web site provides streaming access to an archive of hundreds of hours of spacemusic artfully blended into one-hour programs combining ambient, electronic, world, new-age and classical music." Steve Sande, The Sky's the Limit with Ambient Music, SF Chronicle, Sunday, January 11, 2004 Archived August 11, 2007, at the Wayback Machine
  90. ^ "Star's End" is (with the exception of "Music from the Hearts of Space") the longest running radio program of ambient music in the world. Since 1976, Star's End has been providing the Philadelphia broadcast area with music to sleep and dream to." "Star's End" website background information page Archived 2007-08-14 at the Wayback Machine
  91. ^ "Avaruusromua 25 vuotta radiossa ja kerran televisiossa!". yle.fi. Archived from the original on 2016-06-25.
remarks:
本词条汉字内容由 @多频百科团队 翻译+编辑
原文译自 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ambient_music
name: Ambient
descriptions: Ambient Music（氛围音乐、环境音乐）是一种将重点放在氛围上的音乐风格，不同于传统音乐对音乐结构/节奏/旋律的强调。其没有十分突出的音调，但能唤起人们较强的视听感受。这种类型的音乐会让人沉浸其中乃至于会感觉不到音乐本身。Ambient 强调情绪的表达与氛围的渲染，常常通过高品质的音色以及合音达到目的，正因如此，其缺少一般音乐所具有的节奏感，旋律，以及结构。自然界的音效会通过采样包含其中，而钢琴、弦乐和长笛等乐器的声音会通过合成器来模拟。
originalName: 环境音乐, 氛围音乐
startAddress: United Kingdom, Jamaica (dub music)  and Japan
originalStyle: Electronic, beautiful music, background music, light music, easy listening, furniture, lounge, minimal, experimental, drone, krautrock, dub
affectStyle: Ambient house, ambient techno, biomusic, chill-out, downtempo, IDM, new age, post-rock, space music, trance, trip hop
